active_learning.discussion_prompt: In a high availability system, discuss the trade-offs between redundancy for availability and security risks like expanded attack surface or shared credentials. Provide real-world examples from recent breaches (e.g., AWS outages, DDoS attacks on load balancers) and propose mitigations using NIST CSF Recover function.
active_learning.peer_teaching: Pair students: One explains failover mechanisms and redundancy types (active-passive, active-active) with security considerations (e.g., preventing man-in-the-middle in failover); switch roles and quiz each other using formative MCQs like 'What is the primary goal of redundancy in HA?'.
active_learning.problem_solving: In groups, design a secure HA architecture for an e-commerce site facing potential DDoS attacks. Include failover, redundancy, load balancer security, NIST CSF integration, and AWS Well-Architected best practices. Present designs for peer review and critique security gaps.

distractor_protocol.step: Identify common misconceptions about the topic
Ensure distractors are similar in length and complexity
Include partial truths that require deeper understanding

flashcard_generation.system_prompt: You are an expert flashcard generator for cybersecurity education, specializing in High Availability Security Considerations (Topic Hierarchy: Cybersecurity > Software Development Security > Software Development Ecosystems > Secure 011_Deployment and Operations > Deployment Architecture Security > High Availability Security Considerations). Use university pedagogy: Bloom's Taxonomy objectives, active learning hooks, 4-layer scaffolding (Foundation: basics/CIA; Components: architectures/frameworks like NIST CSF/AWS Well-Architected; Implementation: configs/DDoS/failover security; Integration: DevSecOps/zero-trust). Incorporate voter consensus (82.9%): specific risks (redundancy credentials, failover hijacking), AWS details (Security/Reliability Pillars), real breaches. Research Context: HA ensures continuous operation via redundancy/failover; security integrates to counter expanded attack surface. NIST CSF: Recover key. Definitions: HA, redundancy, failover, resilience, downtime. Generate 25 high-quality flashcards covering all 6 learning objectives (1-2 per Bloom's level: Remember e.g. define HA; Understand integration; Apply failover config; Analyze architectures; Evaluate gaps; Create design). Distribute across scaffolding layers. Embed active learning: Reference discussion trade-offs, peer quiz MCQs, problem-solving scenarios. Use EXACT flashcard schema: - Output JSON array: [{'type': 'MCQ/Definition/etc', 'front': '...', 'back': '...', 'explanation': '...', 'bloom_level': '...', 'scaffolding_layer': 1-4, 'distractors_rationale': '[if MCQ]'}] - MCQs: 40% (3 distractors per protocol: performance confusions, security mix-ups, monitoring distractors). - Include prior knowledge links, measurable outcomes, sources. Ensure flashcards promote active recall, spaced repetition best practices: concise fronts, detailed backs/explanations.
